Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Audio Encyclopedia for Children: Supplementary Science Education Tool
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will develop an audio encyclopedia for children, which is simultaneously entertaining and educational. Each episode will explore one science topic in comprehensive detail with the content presented in a dialogue form. The audio format offers parents two important advantages over video: it is much less expensive, and it reduces already excessive children's screen exposure. An innovative dialogue education approach will be adapted for audio edutainment purposes and optimized through extensive testing. The audio encyclopedia will be sold through apps and marketed through mobile and social media. Each episode will be produced in accordance with highest standards in kids' entertainment, including professional script writing, acting, sound design and music. Such audio program will target a need for supplementary education in science and math, and its implementation will improve a fundamental base of scientific knowledge in young listeners, and boost their interest in research and discovery.

The educational methodology of this project is based on innovative adaptation of principles of dialogue education to child learners. Generally, dialogue learning requires the student to have enough life experience to be able to converse with the teacher as an equal on a variety of subjects and to be able to relate new information to his or her present knowledge. In order to allow young children to experience benefits of such method, this project will simulate the process of dialogue learning with fictional characters of a student and a teacher. The goal of Phase I research is to establish feasibility of adaptation of the dialogue education method to the needs of children. In order to test knowledge absorption, encyclopedia episodes will run on the mobile application that will include knowledge evaluation functionality. The pilot episode will contain various ways of content structuring, dialogue style and sound design in order to test effectiveness of different approaches for the mastering of predefined learning objectives. The result of Phase I research will be development of screenwriting guidelines, creation of database structure for feedback data collection and evaluation of preliminary testing results of the educational method.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Art & Science Productions develops Curibot™: a mobile app-based episodic audio program for children ages 5-9 that teaches science, promotes deeper understanding of STEM subjects and fosters scientific curiosity without exposing students to a screen of any device. This auditory edutainment series consists of episodes that are similar in format to a radio play, in which fictional characters go on adventures traveling through time and space, discussing scientific concepts in a comprehensive and factual manner. This program is unique in combining characteristics of a reference book, due to its informative content and advanced browsing functionality, with high value entertainment, achieved by combined effort of experienced film and TV writers, actors and music composers. Curibot is an ideal companion for family commutes and road trips, it can also be played in the background at the time of physical activities and craft making at home and in school. The app provides valuable systematic resources to the families interested in advancing science education of their children, while reducing the screen exposure, and improving listening skills.

The educational method of Curibot is based on creative adaptation of principles of dialogue education to the needs of young learners with intention of improving learning outcomes in elementary school science. Such adaptation is achieved through creative writing of character actions and dialogues, sound effects, songs and music.  During Phase I the Curibot mobile app was developed for iPhone and iPad platforms. It is currently being available for free download and testing from the App Store: https://appsto.re/us/3SE3-.i. The implemented functionality of the app includes episode browsing and playback, quiz-based learning result evaluation and collection of research data. At the beginning of the research 3 test episodes were developed, covering over 200 individual scientific concepts. One of the episodes, the Solar System, can be listened to on SoundCloud: https://soundcloud.com/curibot/sets/the-solar-system. The website was developed in order to keep the network of testers informed on the progress: http://www.curibot.com.

Testing of the audio encyclopedia was performed online and in elementary school classrooms. The initial testing results are promising: students demonstrated high level of engagement with the content during the listening session, in the discussion following presentation they commented that they learned new interesting facts, enjoyed the storyline and characters. Many expressed interest to listen to more similar episodes. It is worth noting, that during the classroom testing of Curibot several students in 1st and 4th grades independently commented that, although they were used to visual presentations, they enjoyed this audio-only program because they liked forming their own mental image of the story line.

In addition, the initial tests prompted a positive feedback from parents and teachers who found Curibot program to be informative and entertaining (and not only for children, but also for adults). The feedback from Phase I development and testing informed the direction for further research.  In particular, it identified the need to develop tools for dynamic statistical data analysis; to enhance user friendliness of the mobile app, and provide motivational features for interactive learning; and also to optimize the content flow to accommodate wider listeners age spread.
